postsData.name:
Tim Thomson
Tim Thomson
postsData.content:
𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺’𝘀 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺𝘀 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝗡𝗢𝗧 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺𝘀

For years, I thought I had a leadership problem in my MSP.

But really, I had a culture problem.

Every day, my team would bring me issues—big and small—expecting me to have the answers.

 "Hey, what should we do about this client issue?"

 "I’m stuck on this project. What’s the next step?"

 "How do we handle this pricing concern?"

At first, I felt needed. But over time, I became the bottleneck for every decision.

 I was drowning in problem-solving instead of growing the business.

Then, I discovered 1-3-1—a simple shift that changed everything.

𝗜𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗱 𝗼𝗳 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗱𝗿𝗼𝗽𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝗺𝘆 𝗱𝗲𝘀𝗸, 𝗺𝘆 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝗵𝗮𝗱 𝘁𝗼:

 1 Problem – Clearly define the issue.
 3 Possible Solutions – Think critically before asking for help.
 1 Recommendation – Choose the best option and explain why.

The result?

 My team became independent problem-solvers.
 I got time back to focus on strategy and growth.
 We built a culture of accountability instead of dependency.

If you’re feeling like the answer guy in your business, it’s time for a change.

𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝟭-𝟯-𝟭 𝘁𝗼𝗱𝗮𝘆—𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗳𝘂𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝘀𝗲𝗹𝗳 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗸 𝘆𝗼𝘂.

P.S. Have you tried or heard of this before?

P.S.S. Day 10 75 hard, the gym was a banger!

Comment below.

comments.commentText: The 1-3-1 method is a game-changer! By empowering your team to solve problems independently, you not only foster a culture of accountability, but also free up time to focus on growth and strategy. This simple shift can transform both leadership and team dynamics!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insight! Empowering teams to problem-solve independently is a game-changer. Excited to implement the 1-3-1 approach! 💡👏

Chris Miles
Chris Miles
postsData.content:
NEARLY 10 YEARS AGO, I ALMOST QUIT MY BUSINESS... 
AND IT CHANGED MY LIFE! 

Having recently come out of a painful divorce, I questioned whether I should quit my business.

- Business had slowed to a crawl
- I was emotionally overwhelmed
- I didn't like trying to be someone I wasn't
- I wondered if anyone was even listening to my message
- And I was burned out from putting on 6 live multi-day events in 2015, plus presented 187 times that year
....And I was advised to DOUBLE that number!

Would anyone even notice if I quit?

AT THIS LOW POINT, I DECIDED TO DO THE OPPOSITE!

The big change?
I began to listen to my intuition!

- Instead of putting on one multi-day event per month, I was only going to do THREE that year!
- I would only invite people that I wanted there. No more "putting butts in seats."
- I stopped attending networking events, and focused more on my podcast.
- If I didn't feel a "Hell yes!", I turned down speaking engagements.
- Instead of working 50+ hours per week, I began working 5-10 hrs per week

From a rational perspective, my business should have failed, right?

Quite the opposite!

This picture was my 1st event of that year. Instead of 30-50 people in attendance, I had FIVE!

Both couples pictured were MEANT to be here.
Both couples became my clients, and it became my most profitable event of all time!

That year, I cut my speaking engagements down by 35%, my revenue doubled, and my profit 5x'ed!

9 YEARS LATER....

- I work about 25-30 hours per week
- I presented less than 150 times last year (almost all virtual)
- My revenue and profit grew by over 1500%.
- And I'm so much happier!

Lesson - Listen to your intuition, even if others think you're crazy. And keep moving forward!
postsData.commentAdded: What an inspiring journey! Your commitment to intuition over noise is a testament to true leadership. Here’s to thriving on our own terms! 🌟

postsData.content:
Your excellence is the problem.

It's suffocating your team.

8 signs you're managing instead of leading:

1. You Fix Every Problem
🟥 "Let me handle this" keeps your team small
 Replace with: "What do you suggest?"

2. You Attend Every Meeting
🟥 Your presence blocks honest discussion
 Replace with: "Send me the key decisions"

3. You Approve Everything
🟥 Review loops create bottlenecks
 Replace with: "Here's what success looks like"

4. You're Always Available
🟥 Instant help steals growth
 Replace with: "What have you tried so far?"

5. You Avoid Team Conflict
🟥 Peace-keeping builds hidden problems
 Replace with: "Let's address this now"

6. You Work the Longest Hours
🟥 Late nights normalize burnout culture
 Replace with: "Go home, we'll tackle this tomorrow"

7. You Say Yes to Everything
🟥 Taking on more hurts focus
 Replace with: "This isn't a priority"

8. You Love Being the Hero
🟥 Saving the day weakens your team
 Replace with: "This is yours to solve"

The real cost:

Every fix breaks their confidence.
Every answer silences their voice.
Every rescue stops their growth.

Your team is ready.
The question is: are you?

What will you stop fixing today?

postsData.content:
So yesterday, doing some research for PlayBooked I had the occasion to journey to New Orleans for some pre-Super Bowl events, including that at Brand Innovators at an amazing venue off the French Quarter.

Thank you,,for making that happen.

Now, I am not going to the
on Sunday. That isn't the point here.

First, I was astounded at the vibrant atmosphere of New Orleans. Post Katrina, there has been much said about the downfall of New Orleans. I haven't done much to dispel those conversations myself. I go there very sparingly, and don't do much to celebrate the city. But I was impressed by the atmosphere, the show of strength of the police and military (especially after the recent cowardly attack on tourists) and the overall feeling of being a part of something special. Streets were packed, restaurants were busy, and of course, even in the middle of the day, the bars were full.

Second, and we discuss this in the marketing world a lot, there really isn't anything like the energy in and around
events. In a world of highly fragmented avenues and white noise, it's near impossible for brands to reach an audience at scale. The energy and enthusiasm not just during the Super Bowl but in the entire week surrounding the event show that this isn't just a game. It isn't just a show. The closest comparison that I can make is that it is simply one of the world's largest trade shows.

Except in this
there isn't one focus. It's not just about this championship or this game or this sport, but about all sports. It's not about one industry but touches
and
and
and
and
and much more. Oh, and I managed to miss the parties which I am sure is one of the main attractions for the C-Suite and the fans of both teams.

Glad I was able to make it, and look forward to making this a regular occurance.

It’s not about your title, it’s about your impact.⁣
⁣
The 8 most important leadership green flags:⁣
⁣
(here’s what to look for instead)⁣
⁣
1. The Accountability Standard⁣
↳ Takes responsibility before assigning blame⁣
↳ Owns mistakes openly and directly⁣
↳ Creates safety for others to do the same⁣
⁣
2. The Growth Investment⁣
↳ Actively develops team members' skills⁣
↳ Creates opportunities for others to shine⁣
↳ Celebrates when people outgrow roles⁣
⁣
3. The Information Flow⁣
↳ Shares context and knowledge freely⁣
↳ Communicates bad news early⁣
↳ Makes decision-making transparent⁣
⁣
4. The Feedback Loop⁣
↳ Seeks and gives honest feedback regularly⁣
↳ Makes tough conversations normal⁣
↳ Creates two-way dialogue⁣
⁣
5. The Trust Builder⁣
↳ Delegates meaningful work, not just tasks⁣
↳ Gives credit generously and specifically⁣
↳ Shows faith in team's capabilities⁣
⁣
6. The Vision Clarity⁣
↳ Makes complex goals simple and clear⁣
↳ Connects daily work to larger purpose⁣
↳ Creates compelling future stories⁣
⁣
7. The Emotional Intelligence⁣
↳ Reads and manages team energy⁣
↳ Addresses concerns before they become issues⁣
↳ Creates psychological safety⁣
⁣
8. The Work-Life Champion⁣
↳ Models healthy boundaries⁣
↳ Respects personal time⁣
↳ Makes well-being a priority⁣
⁣
True leadership is about growing people, not just achieving goals.⁣
⁣
What else would you add to this list?⁣⁣
Let me know below! ⁣⁣
⁣
️ Followand reshare to help others.⁣⁣
 Save this post for future reference!⁣⁣⁣⁣

From Humble Beginnings to Digital Domination: Nike’s Journey of Innovation

Nike started as a small distributor with a bold vision—to revolutionize athletic footwear. What began with a handshake between Phil Knight and Bill Bowerman in 1964 has grown into a global leader in performance, style, and innovation.

But Nike’s success isn’t just about great shoes—it’s about embracing digital transformation and AI-driven innovation to redefine the way footwear is designed, manufactured, and experienced.

 AI-Driven Personalization – From NIKEiD to smart insoles that analyze movement and optimize comfort, Nike is making shoes that adapt to you—not the other way around.

 Digital Twins & Smart Manufacturing – Using real-time data, IoT, and advanced analytics, Nike has built an agile supply chain that delivers high-quality, high-performance footwear faster than ever.

 Augmented Reality & Immersive Shopping – Virtual try-ons, AI-powered fit recommendations, and interactive digital experiences ensure that customers find the perfect pair before they even step into a store.

isn’t just a footwear company—it’s a technology powerhouse that continues to push boundaries. The fusion of AI, digital design, and customer-driven insights is shaping the future of footwear like never before.

What’s next? Smarter, more sustainable, and even more connected shoes. The future of performance and style is being written in real time—and Nike is leading the way.

postsData.content:
An objection can feel like a slap in the face (if you don't know how to handle it)

How I handle top 10 sales objections:

Every objection is an opportunity for discovery - peel the onion.

1 “Email me in 3 months"
- What will happen in 3 months?

2 “I’m not interested"
- Before I leave - Is <challenge> a priority right now? if not, what is?

3 “Too expensive”
- It sounds like you're comparing this to what you already have or just the value isn't there for you. Which one is it?

4 “We don’t have the budget”
- Budget aside, is this even close to a priority for 2025?

5 “I’m locked into a contract with a competitor”
- Anything you’d want to improve with your current solution?

6 “tried it & it didn’t work for us”
- Could you tell me more about what didn’t work?

7 “We just signed a contract with a provider”
- Would you want to explore other options before renewal, just to compare?

8 “We already use a competitor”
- Would you be open to hearing 3 ways we differ?

9 “All set for now”
- Just so I’m clear, what’s working well that you feel all set on?

10 I’m too busy right now
- Is there a better time, or should I send a quick summary by email?

Don't fight the objection, get to the real why.

That's the art of verbal judo.

How do you handle objections?

PS. I`m, follow me for tips on how to drive revenue from LinkedIn & Email

comments.commentText: Objections aren’t roadblocks—they’re just detours to the real conversation. Ask the right question, and suddenly, "not interested" turns into "tell me more."
Neil Sarkar it’s one step from: „hmm, tell me more”

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Transforming objections into opportunities truly sets top salespeople apart. What’s been your biggest learning in this process?

postsData.content:
Telekinesis for Startups and Business?

Thinking Big: How to "Telekinetically" Achieve Business Goals 

While telekinesis, the ability to move objects with your mind, may reside in the realm of science fiction, the concept of harnessing the power of thought and intention resonates deeply within the entrepreneurial spirit.

Just as a telekinetic might "will" an object to move, successful  businesses and startups demonstrate the power of:

1. Visionary Leadership: True leaders, like Steve Jobs or Elon Musk, possess a powerful vision that "telekinetically" guides their companies. They inspire teams, attract talent, and drive innovation through the sheer force of their belief in a better future.
2. Focused Intention: High-performing teams channel their energy towards specific goals, much like a telekinetic focusing their mental energy to achieve a desired outcome. This focus, often cultivated through mindfulness and goal-setting methodologies, drives efficiency and accelerates progress.
3. Customer-Centricity: Understanding and anticipating customer needs is paramount. Successful businesses "telekinetically" sense customer desires, adapting products and services to meet evolving demands. This involves deep empathy, market research, and a relentless focus on customer feedback.
4. Innovation through Focused Energy: Breakthrough innovations often emerge from a confluence of focused thought and creative energy. By fostering a culture of experimentation and encouraging out-of-the-box thinking, startups can "telekinetically" manifest novel solutions and disrupt existing markets.
5. Teamwork as a Force Multiplier: High-performing teams leverage the combined energy and focus of their members, creating a powerful synergy that drives progress and achieves ambitious goals. This collective intention amplifies individual efforts, much like combining individual forces to achieve a greater outcome.

 Examples in Action:

1. Tesla: Elon Musk's visionary leadership and unwavering belief in sustainable transportation have "telekinetically" driven the company's rapid growth and innovation.
2. Airbnb: The platform's founders "telekinetically" envisioned a world where people could easily share their homes with travelers, disrupting the traditional hospitality industry.
3. Google: The company's mission to "organize the world's information and make it universally accessible" has guided its development of innovative products like search, maps, and AI, shaping how we interact with the digital world.

Our minds, the principles of focused intention, visionary leadership, and harnessing collective energy are fundamental to achieving success in business and entrepreneurship. Share your insights below

Ancient Japanese wisdom holds the key to modern leadership.
These timeless principles have shaped global giants like Toyota.

Thank you to my friend,, for this stunning carousel.

Amidst the sea of modern frameworks, 8 Japanese concepts stand out.
They've transformed countless leaders.

And they might just change how you think  too.

1. 𝗪𝗮𝗯𝗶-𝗦𝗮𝗯𝗶 (侘寂) — Embrace Imperfection
↳ Accept and learn from your mistakes
↳ Build trust through embracing imperfection

2. 𝗜𝗸𝗶𝗴𝗮𝗶 (生き甲斐) — Living Your Purpose
↳ Map the intersection of what energizes you and what impacts others
↳ Align your strengths with opportunities that serve a bigger mission

3. 𝗞𝗮𝗶𝘇𝗲𝗻 (改善) — Continuous Improvement
↳ Focus on being 1% better every day
↳ Small, consistent improvements lead to extraordinary growth

4. 𝗞𝗶𝗻𝘁𝘀𝘂𝗴𝗶 (金継ぎ) — The Art of Repairing with Gold
↳ Transform your challenges into something more beautiful
↳ Let your setbacks become your strength

5. 𝗦𝗵𝗶𝗯𝘂𝗶 (渋い) — Less is More
↳ Embrace simplicity in your communication
↳ Make every word count

6. 𝗜𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗴𝗼 𝗜𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗲 (一期一会) — Every Moment Matters
↳ Treat each interaction as a unique opportunity
↳ Build connections through genuine presence

7. 𝗠𝗮 (間) — Strategic Silence
↳ Create deliberate pauses for clarity
↳ Use space between actions to amplify their impact

8. 𝗚𝗮𝗺𝗮𝗻 (我慢) — Resilient Leadership
↳ Navigate challenges with calm dignity
↳ Practice patience in the face of adversity

These aren't just concepts.
They're powerful tools for transforming how you lead, work, and live.

Which of these principles have you applied? Would love to hear below

postsData.content:
8 paradoxes of natural charisma

Being likable isn't about what you think. 

Some people have a effortless talent to draw others in.

Why?

Because authenticity is more compelling than perfection.

Most people try to be likable by:

- Being endlessly agreeable
- Filling every silence
- Hiding their flaws
- Playing it safe

These strategies backfire because they make you forgettable.

Here's what actually works:

1. Create moments of uncertainty
The most captivating people aren't predictable:
- Let silences linger
- Break patterns subtly
 Your slight unpredictability makes others lean in.

2. Embrace selective discomfort
True confidence isn't about being comfortable everywhere:
- Share unpopular opinions
- Skip events that drain you
 Comfort with rejection makes others feel safe being real.

3. Show your rough edges
Stop hiding your imperfections:
- Laugh at your mistakes
- Share your learning moments
 Real flaws beat curated perfection every time.

4. Break tiny social rules
The most magnetic people ignore small conventions:
- Answer questions with questions
- Challenge subtle norms
 Small rebellions make others question their own limits.

5. Lead with curiosity
Trade proving yourself for learning:
- Ask the "obvious" questions
- Show genuine interest
 Your willingness to learn makes others feel valued.

6. Match your true energy
Stop performing what you think others want:
- Show your tiredness
- Express real excitement
 Authentic energy draws people closer.

7. Create space for others
Most rush to fill gaps. Instead:
- Let silence breathe
- Give thoughts room to land
 Your comfort creates safety for connection.

8. Set clear boundaries
The most likable people aren't always available:
- Say no directly
- Protect your energy
 Strong boundaries signal self-respect.

What unexpected trait makes someone magnetic to you?

️ Share this with someone who needs to hear it
 Followfor more insights on building a life with purpose

comments.commentText: Authenticity is magnetic. People are drawn to those who own who they are, rather than trying to be what they think others want. Real charisma comes from being comfortable with silence, showing your imperfections, and setting clear boundaries. It is not about saying the right things, it is about creating space for real connection.
Sven, authenticity and silence create a genuine, powerful connection.

postsData.commentAdded: Incredible insights! Embracing authenticity truly captivates others. Everyone should prioritize genuine connections over perfection. Thanks for sharing!

postsData.content:
Why Do Great Employees Leave ? It’s Not Always About the Paycheck !

You might think a bigger salary or fancy perks are the secret to keeping your team happy, but the truth goes much deeper. Most employees leave not because of the money—but because of how they feel at work.

Let’s uncover the REAL reasons behind the revolving door and how to fix them :

 Why They Leave :

1️⃣ Toxic Work Culture: Negativity drains energy. People thrive where positivity flows.
2️⃣ Micromanagement: Employees need trust and space to innovate—not someone watching their every move.
3️⃣ Lack of Leadership: Without strong guidance, teams feel lost and disengaged.
4️⃣ No Balance: Burnout happens when work eats into life. Flexibility shows respect .
5️⃣ Feeling Undervalued: Fair pay and genuine appreciation go a long way .
6️⃣ Invisible Efforts: Recognize and celebrate contributions—small or big .
7️⃣ No Clear Direction: Ambiguity kills motivation. Clarity fuels productivity .
8️⃣ Office Drama: Gossip and unresolved conflicts breed frustration. Open communication is key .
9️⃣ No Growth Opportunities: If there’s no ladder to climb, they’ll look for one elsewhere .
 Zero Purpose: People want to contribute to something meaningful, not just clock in and out .

 What We Can Learn :

️ Culture is king—it sets the tone for everything.
️ Empowerment beats micromanagement every time.
️ Balance and purpose aren’t “extras”—they’re essentials for happy, loyal teams.

Action Time :
Take a moment to reflect :

Are you creating an environment that inspires, supports, and values your team?

If not, what small changes can you make today to turn things around?
 Your thoughts?

Have you experienced any of these issues, or have you found solutions that work ? Let’s discuss in the comments—your input might just inspire someone else!

️ Repost this to spread awareness—because happy employees build great companies.

One of the best things you can do to improve your sales skills is this:

Record yourself.
Recording yourself making cold calls.
Handling objections.
Running sales meetings.

Listen like it’s someone else on the call.
Be brutally honest.

For most people, the simple act of hearing themselves is a game-changer.
When you’re on a call, you’re often thinking about what to say next.
You’re not fully aware of how you actually sound.

after doing this exercise you will feel like this:

“I didn’t realize I sounded like that.”
“I need to stop saying that.”
“I can’t believe I missed that opportunity.”

It’s the fastest way to get better.

Career Resilience in Medical Sales


I’ll never forget the day my career took an unexpected turn.

Newly married, with a newborn at home, I was all-in on my company’s mission—until a robotic Human Resouce Executive on a Friday afternoon conference call changed everything:

“𝑊𝑒 ℎ𝑎𝑣𝑒 𝑑𝑒𝑐𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑑 𝑡𝑜 𝑟𝑒𝑑𝑢𝑐𝑒 𝑡ℎ𝑒 𝑤𝑜𝑟𝑘𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑐𝑒 𝑏𝑦 10%. 𝑌𝑜𝑢𝑟 𝑙𝑎𝑠𝑡 𝑑𝑎𝑦 𝑖𝑠 [𝑋].”

Just like that, I was out. Terrified. Angry. Completely blindsided.

𝐇𝐞𝐫𝐞’𝐬 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐈 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐝 𝐰𝐚𝐲:

 Plan for the unexpected.
↳ No job is guaranteed.

 Be cautiously loyal.
↳ Companies make business decisions, not personal ones.

 Know the signs.
↳ Budget cuts, hiring freezes, and leadership exits are red flags.

 Stay prepared.
↳ Expand your network, develop new skills, and track industry trends.

Career resilience isn’t about avoiding setbacks—it’s about being ready for them. If you lost your job tomorrow, would you be prepared?

Karma is often perceived as a simple equation: good actions bring positive outcomes, while bad actions bring suffering. This perspective, while true on a surface level, overlooks the deeper, spiritual truth that karma is not just about retribution or reward—it is a vast, intricate dance of energy. It is less about an external power balancing the scales and more about the soul’s evolution through its own choices and consequences.

In the spiritual context, karma functions as a mirror, reflecting the intentions and energy we project into the universe. Rather than an external force imposing balance, it is the soul itself learning through experience—its own wisdom shaping the circumstances it encounters. Karma can be seen as a tool for refinement, guiding us back to our true nature by helping us understand the interconnectedness of all beings.

Rather than viewing karma as a rigid system of balance, it can be seen as an opportunity for conscious awakening, a divine invitation to transcend dualities of good and bad, and instead live in alignment with love, compassion, and the higher truths of existence.

postsData.content:
The most dangerous words in leadership

"I'll handle this for you"

Ever caught yourself saying this?

It feels good.

Helpful. Like you're doing your job as a leader.

But here's the brutal truth...

Every time you step in to 'fix' a problem, you're actually:

→ Stunting your team's growth
→ Dimishing their confidence
→ Teaching them to depend on you

And the worst part?

You're doing it with the best intentions.

I used to be that leader.

Feeling good and "needed" for having the answer to help. The "fixer."

Until I could see that my team had stopped thinking for themselves.

postsData.content:
The truth about the weekend hustle:


It steals more than it gives.
(And the price tag is bigger than you think.)

The harsh reality?
While everyone's bragging about their 24/7 grind, 66% of Americans are hiding their trembling hands, forgotten relationships, and midnight anxiety attacks.

Think you're different?
→ Your body's keeping score
→ Your relationships are fading
→ Your creativity's running on fumes

The weekend warriors are lying to you.
(Their "rise and grind" posts? Usually scheduled from burnout's edge)

The truth is:
The most powerful moves are made after the deepest recovery.

5 Power Moves for This Weekend:
1. Calendar Lockdown
→ Block 3-hour chunks of pure silence.
→ Mark yourself "Away" (and mean it).

2. Digital Detox
→ Delete Slack (temporarily).
→ Turn your phone grayscale.
→ Log out of everything work-related.

3. Energy Rituals
→ Create a "shut down" ceremony.
→ Design your rest space.
→ Choose activities that fill you up.

4. Boundary Defense
→ Draft your "no" templates.
→ Share your offline hours.
→ Let the FOMO fuel your focus.

5. Permission Slip
→ Treat rest like fuel, not a favor.
→ Block it. Defend it. Own it.
→ Recharge now, dominate later.

The real winners?
They're strategically resting for Monday's breakthrough.

What's your rest strategy for this weekend?
I'm listening.

️ Share if you're choosing rest over regret

postsData.name:
Rachel Carrell
Rachel Carrell
postsData.content:
A boss makes people anxious.
A leader makes people feel safe.

When leaders focus on defending their own egos, they create a culture of competition and fear.
Team members are hesitant to speak up, and innovation stalls.
Instead, focus on prioritising the right solution - regardless of the source.

There are so many ways to do this in practice:
- Admit your mistakes first
- Offer praise in team channels
- Ask “What do you think?” regularly
- Celebrate risk-taking, even if it fails
- Celebrate small wins publicly, often
- Hold “teach me” sessions frequently
- Push personal growth at every review
- Model humility when big wins happen
- Ask questions instead of giving orders
- Start meetings with personal check-ins
- Share customer stories to align purpose
- Spend time mentoring beyond your team
- Rotate leadership roles for special projects
- Give immediate, sincere acknowledgments
- Create anonymous idea-submission channels
- Encourage open disagreement without penalty

When you create a culture of collaboration and trust, everyone feels empowered to contribute and ideas flow freely.

Don’t be a boss, be a leader.

What’s been your experience?

 Repost to share with your network, and followfor more like this
postsData.commentAdded: Love this perspective! Leadership rooted in trust and collaboration fosters innovation. What strategies have you found most effective?

Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
postsData.content:
Employees should never be blindsided by a termination, if they are, it's on the manager. 

Let’s put the manager on a PIP. If an employee has no clue about a legitimate termination, the manager has failed them and failed at their job.

When it comes to their employment, employees deserve ️

 transparency
 to know where they stand and how they are viewed.
 to know when they are doing well and be praised and rewarded.
 to know when they are not meeting the standard and what they need to improve on.

It should not...
 be in the form of a PIP
 it should not come with the threat of termination
 that only causes more stress and less performance.

It should be regular and ongoing feedback and coaching. With proper communication and coaching there should never be a need for a PIP.

If there is regular coaching and support and the employee is not cutting it then plan a departure, not more coaching that did not work in the first place.

Not every employee is a good fit in an organization. Delaying the inevitable is not good for either party.

If an employee received proper training, coaching, feedback and support they would never be blindsided by a termination. They would know it is coming. A termination should never come as a surprise.

postsData.name:
Dr Alexander Young
Dr Alexander Young
postsData.content:
Focus Isn’t About Doing More.

It’s About Doing Less—But Better.

In a world that rewards busyness,
It’s easy to think that doing more equals success.

But real productivity isn’t about filling your day with tasks.
It’s about focusing on what truly moves the needle.

Here’s how to work smarter, not harder:

1. 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘇𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝘀𝘁
→ Not all tasks are created equal. The 80/20 rule shows that 80% of results come from 20% of efforts.
 The Fix: Identify your highest-impact tasks and focus on them first.

2. 𝗦𝗮𝘆 𝗡𝗼 𝗠𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗢𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗻
→ Every “yes” to a distraction is a “no” to deep work.
 The Fix: Protect your time by setting clear boundaries and eliminating unnecessary meetings.

3. 𝗕𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗸 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗙𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲
→ Multitasking drops productivity by 40%.
 The Fix: Use time blocks to focus on one thing at a time without interruptions.

4. 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗧𝗼 𝗣𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺 𝗕𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿
→ The brain works best in focused sprints, not endless hours of work.
 The Fix: Take regular breaks to recharge and maintain high performance.

5. 𝗠𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘀, 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗧𝗮𝘀𝗸𝘀
→ Being busy isn’t the same as being productive.
 The Fix: Track outcomes, not just activity, to ensure you’re making meaningful progress.

Focusing isn’t about cramming more into your day.
It’s about removing the noise so you can do what truly matters.

What’s your #1 focus strategy?
Let me know in the comments below 

---

postsData.name:
Charlotte Lloyd
Charlotte Lloyd
postsData.content:
My son closed me on getting a puppy and I didn’t even see it coming.

The other day, he asked for a dog.

Not just any dog, the one my friend has.
(The cute dachshund in the photo)

I said no.

But he didn’t stop.

First, he hit me with logic:
“Mom, I’ll take care of it. I’ll feed it, walk it—everything.”

Then, urgency:
“What if someone else adopts him first?”

And finally, emotion:
“I’ll remember this forever if we bring him home.”

And just like that - I caved.

Not because he begged.
Not because he wore me down.

But because he tapped into what actually mattered to me:

I want him to learn responsibility.
I don’t want to regret saying no to sthg meaningful.
I love the idea of a dog bringing joy to our home.
I want to create lasting memories.

And that’s exactly how sales works.

People don’t buy because of
logic, urgency, or persuasion tactics.

They buy because something about your offer
SPEAKS to what they TRULY want.

The best business owners don’t convince.
They listen. They understand.
They meet people where they are.

Want more clients?
Stop selling features.
Start speaking to what actually MOVES them.

Because when your offer aligns with what your ideal client really wants
THEY SELL themselves on working with you.

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 4 – Update Agent LEARNING
Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (,)

A report in Quanta magazine () provides an example: The idea of a “bank” has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. “It’s more abstract, really different from what you’re seeing,” said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3.



In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not “know” anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights on learning and memory! Integrating neuroscience into AI models could revolutionize how we approach expertise. Looking forward to Part 5!

I Generated 158 Sales Meetings From Intel-Driven Outreach Last Year
Then Closed 215 More This Year Using The Same Blueprint
Every win came from my "SPOT" framework:
S - Signal Detection
P - Pain Point
O - Opportunity Link
T - Tactical Ask
𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 1: 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐒𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐃𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧
 "Hope you're having a great quarter..."
 "Noticed your Q3 media spend increased 40% in streaming"
 "I'm reaching out because we help brands..."
 "Your recent partnership with [Platform] caught my eye"
3 Keys:
 First 8 words must show you've done research - preview text is everything
 Spend 5 min mining: AdTech platforms, media spend reports, partnership news
 Ensure signal connects directly to your solution
𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩 2: 𝐏𝐚𝐢𝐧 𝐏𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐌𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐧 𝐁𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐈𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐜𝐭 > 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐭 𝐅𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞𝐬

Target role-specific challenges they're likely facing.

I've edited hundreds of LinkedIn videos, but one mistake cost me 1,000 views.

It killed engagement.

People scrolled past.

Here’s what went wrong—and how I fixed it:

1. My hook was too slow.

The first 3 seconds didn’t grab attention.

People lost interest fast.

How I fixed it:

I cut out the fluff.

Started with a bold statement or a big question.

2. The pacing was off.

Long pauses and slow cuts made the video drag.

How I fixed it:

I tightened the edits.

Removed dead space.

Kept the energy high.

3. No captions.

Most people watch on mute.

Without subtitles, they skipped.

How I fixed it:

I added bold, easy-to-read captions.

After making these changes, my views doubled.

Small edits make a big difference.

Fix them, and your videos will perform better instantly.

postsData.content:
When I I became a Strategic Account Director for the first time, there was only one account I wanted to close: a $45B global airline. It took me 9 months, and we ended up winning a $5.9M deal.

Here’s how I did it, play-by-play ↓


BACKSTORY:

I joined a Conversational AI company as a Strategic Account Director focused on CX transformation with Fortune 500 brands. On day 1, this was the account I was obsessed with winning above all others because I was a loyal flier and top customer with them.


THE BLUEPRINT:

1. Used the airline for the basis of my onboarding pitch.

During my first week of boot camp at my new company, we had to pick a brand to pitch, and I chose them. It went horribly wrong, but the good thing is that it was in front of internal stakeholders.

I learned so much about our product through my mistakes, but I learned even more about the airline through my extensive research.


2. Wrote an open letter for the airline executives based on my customer experience.

Here was the winning structure:

• Kept it brief (2-3 min read)

• Stated my case (importance of giving time back to customers, like me, using their visuals)

• Defined a path forward (gave specific ideas they could use)

• Delivered credibility (our brief history and a non-competitive customer example)

• Provided a compelling call-to-action (invite to an exclusive peer event in London)


3. Sent an email to 5 execs with a private link to the open letter.

Here was the email:

Hello S**********,

As I write this from the <airline’s lounge>, I was reminded of just how many miles I fly when I received your letter with my annual <club membership> (attached).

I have been a <airline> loyalist for several years and this year is shaping up to be the year I finally hit <highest tier> status!

The experiences I receive from <airline>; from the friendly greetings at the gate, to the hospitality at the lounges, to the mobile app experience are all top notch!

But...

Link: Read The Open Letter to VPs

Look forward to connecting!

Brandon


4. I also sent physical packages to arrive on the same day as the email.

The packages included:

• High-quality materials
• Initial business case using public-facing info
• Invitation to validate our numbers and connect

A few days after this was done, I received calls from 3 direct reports to the VPs I sent everything to.

That led to a successful 9-month engagement where we beat several competitors to win their business.


Bold, prepared, and creative wins.

Especially in this market!

Want to read the exact open letter I sent?

Unlock it here:

(Bonus inside)

Create. Explore. Experiment.
This simple slogan at T-Works got me thinking deeply. 

We often mistake repetition for progress but doing the same thing 100 times without learning isn’t growth, it’s wasted effort.

 Exploring means we should step out of our comfort zones and seek knowledge that truly adds value. Sticking to the familiar won't lead us to new opportunities.
 Experimenting means we should embrace failure as a learning tool, adjusting our approach and trying again. Growth happens when we adapt, not when we repeat.
 Creating means we should innovate and take action, instead of simply reusing old ideas. It’s about bringing new things to life and making a real impact.

The world rewards those who are curious enough to explore, brave enough to experiment, and bold enough to create.
So ask yourself:
 Are you truly learning, or just repeating?
 Are you evolving, or just circling the same path?
Break the cycle. Learn. Adapt. Move forward. 

What’s one thing you changed after realizing repetition wasn’t working? Let’s discuss in the comments!

𝐄𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐄𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐓𝐢𝐩𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐤𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐜𝐞 

Effective email communication is crucial in a professional environment, as it helps maintain clarity, professionalism, and efficiency. Here are some essential email practices:

1.Use a Clear and Concise Subject Line

- Your subject line should summarize the main point of your email. It allows recipients to prioritize their reading. Keep it brief and to the point.

- Example: "Meeting Rescheduled to Friday, 3 PM" instead of "Meeting Update."

2. Greet Appropriately

- Always use a proper greeting such as "Dear [Name]," or "Hello [Name]," depending on your relationship with the recipient. Using a more formal tone for colleagues or clients you don't know well is a safe bet.


3. Be Clear and Direct

- Get to the point early in your email. Be concise and avoid unnecessary details or jargon. Busy professionals appreciate emails that are easy to read and action.
- Use bullet points or numbered lists if you have multiple points or actions to communicate.

4. Use Professional Language

- Maintain professionalism in tone and language. Avoid slang, emojis, or overly casual language unless your workplace culture permits it.
- Be mindful of your tone to avoid sounding too demanding or informal.

5. Proofread Before Sending

- Always proofread for grammar, spelling, and punctuation errors. Typos can make you look careless or unprofessional.
- Double-check names and other details to ensure accuracy.

6. Use Proper Formatting

- Avoid sending long, unbroken paragraphs. Break up your text into readable sections.
- Use short paragraphs, subheadings, and bullet points when appropriate.
- Stick to a clean, readable font (like Arial or Calibri) and avoid using colors or unusual formatting unless necessary.

7. Be Mindful of the "Reply All" Button

- Only use "Reply All" when necessary. Consider if everyone on the email needs to see your response. Overuse of "Reply All" can clutter inboxes.

8. Respond Promptly

- Aim to respond to work emails within 24 hours, even if it's just to acknowledge receipt and indicate when you'll provide a detailed response.

9. Use Email Signatures

- Include a professional email signature with your full name, job title, company name, and contact information.
- A simple signature adds professionalism and makes it easy for others to contact you.

10. Respect Recipients' Time

- Keep emails as brief and to the point as possible. People are more likely to read and respond to your email if they don’t have to sift through excessive text.
- If an email requires a response, make sure to ask for one in a polite and clear manner.

postsData.content:
Your energy is everything.
But most people waste it without even noticing.
Not because they do too much. But because they spend it on the wrong things.


 Saying yes when you want to say no.
 Over-explaining when silence would do.
 Forcing small talk when you’d rather listen.
 Keeping up with conversations that drain you.


You feel it.


That heaviness after too much people time.
The exhaustion of trying to keep up.


It is not just in your head.

Your energy is not infinite.


Ever had a conversation that left you completely drained?
Sat through a meeting where you barely spoke, yet felt exhausted after?
Agreed to plans, then spent the whole time wishing you were home?

That is not just social fatigue.
That is energy leakage.


And here is the thing.

It adds up. 


Every time you give your energy away without intention,
you have less for what actually matters.

 Less for deep work.
 Less for real connection.
 Less for the things that make you feel alive.


Every choice either fuels you or drains you. ️


And when you protect it,
everything changes.


 More focus.
 More presence.
 More ease in how you move through the world.


Protecting your energy is not selfish.
It is survival.


Now.
Imagine what you could build with that energy.

 The ideas you could bring to life.
 The life you could create on your terms.


Your energy is yours.
Spend it where it truly matters.



I am, and my mission is to help introverted entrepreneurs and professionals thrive as they are while protecting their energy to focus on their dreams.

postsData.content:
9 Best Pieces of ADVICE for anyone who wants to grow on LinkedIn: 

1. Be yourself.

2. Consistency wins—show up even when you think no one is watching.

3. Hooks matter—your first sentence should make people need to read the next.

4. Your personal stories and experiences are gold—use them.

5. Stop worrying about what others might think.

6. Don’t get stuck overthinking your profile aesthetics or branding.

7. Stop waiting for the "perfect" moment or the best tools—just start writing.

8. Focus on providing value through your content.

9. Perfection kills momentum—write, post, improve, repeat.
postsData.commentAdded: Great tips! Embracing authenticity and consistency can truly transform your LinkedIn journey. Time to take action and share our stories! 💪✨

postsData.name:
Anshuman Tiwari
Anshuman Tiwari
postsData.content:
The first time I conducted a class was in my 2nd year in Engineering. And that's when I realised I liked teaching. 

But, why was I teaching my own class?

The year was 1991.

Our Industrial Management Professor had this unique idea to give out key topics to students and let them conduct the class for 5 minutes or so. He thought the idea was unique but I know he was lazy.

But this story is not about him. It's about me discovering that I can teach.

I had taught earlier. During my college days I had taught some school students so I did have some interest.

But teaching your own class is a different level.

My topic - How to Motivate a General Manager at SAIL.

SAIL is Steel Authority of India. The topic was chosen well. In those days the general belief was that no one really works in public sector. Wrong but belief is belief.

By this time I knew I had severe confidence issues when speaking in public. I would stutter and stammer. But I also knew that the only way out was to prepare well and get as much practice I could.

Most importantly - I wanted to get better. I knew I had to.

I poured myself in the assignment. Spent hours in the library. Studied multiple chapters on Motivation. Made my notes. Planned my session. All this for 5 mins.

I had material for 5 hrs but the allotted time was 5 mins. but then I was 19 and naive.

I was to go second. First speaker finished his 5 min class in 2 mins.

We had about 40 students in the class from what I recall. I opened with a question that I still feel shaped how I think ---

Before we think HOW we should motivate someone, WHY should we need to do so?

And this question paved the way for me to build my teaching style. I conduct the class for the remaining 40 mins of the lecture. My fellow students kept encouraging me and later told me - I taught way better than the Prof.

And I knew they were right. Even the most uninterested students were actually listening in my class.

I learnt three key lessons that day. Lessons that I hold dear till today -

1. If you prepare well, confidence is a by-product

2. If you like doing something, pouring yourself into it is easy

3. If you want to get better you have to be ready to start at the bottom.

What started as a lazy approach to teaching from our Prof., changed my career.

This was the talk where I knew I was onto something. I knew I had turned the corner from being an under-confident speaker to someone who will try. I understood the value of preparation. And the most important lesson - you don't get better if you don't try.

And for these reasons, I remain forever grateful to Prof.

Did any such chance episode change something deep for you? Want to share?

++++
Photos - some recent photos of me teaching :)
postsData.commentAdded: What a powerful journey of self-discovery! Your experience exemplifies how stepping out of our comfort zones can lead to incredible growth. Thank you for sharing!
